Analyzing the Graph of \( y = e^{-x-3} \) Using First and Second Derivative Tests

Step 1: Find the First Derivative

To find the first derivative \( y' \) of \( y = e^{-x-3} \), we differentiate directly with respect to \( x \):

\[ y = e^{-x-3} \]

item.title: 4.5 Practice
item.description:
Ex1. Analyze and sketch the graph of the function \( f(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x - 1 \).

Solution Write the given function: \[ f(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x - 1 \]

Step 1: Domain

The domain of \( f(x) \) is all real numbers: \( (-\infty, \infty) \).

Step 2: Intercepts

  • \( y \)-intercept: Set \( x = 0 \):
    \[ f(0) = (0)^3 - 4(0)^2 + 5(0) - 1 = -1 \] (\( y \)-intercept is \( (0, -1) \)).
  • \( x \)-intercepts: Solve \( f(x) = 0 \). Factoring may be challenging here, so numerical or graphical methods can be used.

Step 3: First Derivative Test

\[ f'(x) = 3x^2 - 8x + 5 \]\[ 3x^2 - 8x + 5 = 0 \implies x = \frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{(-8)^2 - 4(3)(5)}}{2(3)} = \frac{8 \pm \sqrt{64 - 60}}{6} = \frac{8 \pm 2}{6} \]


Critical points: \( x = \frac{10}{6} = \frac{5}{3} \) and \( x = 1 \).
